datasetPresenter.displayName: C. parvum Iowa II genome sequence and annotation from Genbank
datasetPresenter.description:
Whole genome sequence and annotations from the C. parvum whole genome sequencing project.
References:
Complete genome sequence of the apicomplexan, Cryptosporidium parvum. Science 2004 Apr 16;304(5669):441-5 Abrahamsen et al.

Parasites
C. parvum isolate TU114 was isolated from a Ugandan child in 2003 and has since been maintained by serial propagation in immunosuppressed mice. This isolate was previously described in the context of a crossing experiment (Tanriverdi et al., 2007). TU114 was genotyped with several polymorphic micro- and minisatellite markers (Tanriverdi & Widmer, 2006, Widmer & Lee, 2010). Its genotype is characteristic of a group of C. parvum isolates which are predominantly or exclusively transmitted among humans and carry the GP60 (GP40/15) IIcA5G3b allele characterized by a short repeat of only 8 serine residues. Isolate TU114 has never been cloned. To generate DNA for sequencing, immunosuppressed CD-1 mice were orally inoculated with oocysts. When oocysts were first detected in the feces by the microscopic analysis of stained fecal smears (Ma & Soave, 1983), mice were transferred to cages with a wire bottom and feces collected daily. Oocysts were purified on step gradients of Histodenz (Widmer et al., 1998). To remove foreign DNA, oocysts were briefly suspended in a 10% solution of commercial bleach. Thereafter, oocysts were subjected to three cycles of freezing and thawing, and DNA extracted with the HighPure DNA isolation kit (Roche Diagnostics, Indianapolis, IN).

Sequencing Genomic DNA from isolate TU114 was fragmented, ligated to Illumina adapters and the library loaded onto one lane of a flow cell. The library was sequenced in an Illumina Genome AnalyzerII with 50-bp paired-end reads. A total of 22,125,448 reads were obtained, 21,483,810 (97.15%) of which mapped to the C. parvum reference genome (accession # NZ AAEE00000000).
Peptides from linear ion trap (LTQ) mass spectrometer analysis of C. parvum oocyst walls.

datasetPresenter.displayName: C. parvum Chr6 scaffold sequence and annotation from Genbank
datasetPresenter.description:
C. parvum chromosome 6 sequenced at the MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, Cambridge, UK.
The tRNA genes from the original GenBank record have been assigned unofficial locus_tags for the purposes of display in CryptoDB.
References:
Integrated mapping, chromosomal sequencing and sequence analysis of Cryptosporidium parvum. Genome Res. 2003 Aug;13(8):1787-99 Bankier et al.

C. parvum sporozoite peptides from 2D gel LC-MS/MS analysis.

J.M. Wastling, S. Sanderson, D. Xia and A.Z. Siddiki.
Departments of Pre-Clinical Veterinary Science & Veterinary Pathology
University of Liverpool
Crown Street, Liverpool, United Kingdom L69 7ZJ

Isolates MD and TU114, were maintained and crossed in adult immunosuppressed C57BL/6 mice (1 mg dexamethasone phosphate administered every second day (Yang et al., 2000)). Six days after the first injection, mice were infected orally with ~1000 oocysts. Oocysts were purified from mouse feces as previously described (Widmer et al., 1998). Briefly, samples were homogenized and the oocysts floated on a 15%/30% (w/v) Histodenz (N,N'-bis(2,3-dihydroxypropyl)acetamido-2,4,6-tri-iodo-isophthalamide) (Sigma, St. Louis, Miss.) step gradient. Oocysts were sometimes further purified with immunomagnetic separation using the Aureon Crypto Kit (Aureon Biosystems, Vienna, Austria). DNA was extracted from purified oocysts with the High Pure Template Preparation Kit (Roche Diagnostics, Indianapolis, Ind.) (Tanriverdi et al., 2002). DNA was eluted in 20-50 ul TE buffer, a concentration equivalent to 10^4 oocysts/ul. SNPs differentiating the isolates MD and TU114 were identified by sequencing randomly chosen fragments of 2-2.5 kb retrieved from the C. parvum genome sequence. Fragments were spaced at approximately 80 kb. PCR primers 20-30 bp long were designed with vector NTI software. PCR included approximately 10 ng DNA of parental isolates MD or TU114, 0.4 µM primers and PCR mix (Takara) to a final volume of 50µl. Amplifications were performed with the following temperature condition: denaturation at 94°C for 2 min was followed by 35 cycles of 94°C for 30 s, 50-55°C for 30 sec, 68°C for 1.5 2 min, and a final 5 min extension at 68°C. A portion of 5µl of each PCR product was run on 1% agarose. For PCR reactions giving a single band, 5µl PCR product was treated with 2 µl of ExoSAP-IT (USB) at 37°C for 30 min and 80°C for 15 min. If multiple PCR bands were present, the entire PCR reaction was run on a 1% agarose gel and the desired band extracted with a QIAquick gel extraction. PCR products were sequenced using two pairs of primers of opposite polarity located at 700-800 bp intervals. Primers were designed such that adjacent complementary sequences overlapped by 50-100 bp. Portions of approximately 50 ng PCR product (~50 ng) were used in 15 µl sequencing reactions (CEQ DTCS-Quick Start Kit). Sequencing reactions were run on a CEQ8000 Genetic Analysis System (Beckman Coulter). Sequences were analyzed the Contig Express program in Vector NTI. MD and TU114 sequences were aligned to find SNPs. Any SNP was confirmed in a minimum of two sequences. Some SNPs were also confirmed by independent PCR amplification of the genomic DNA .

datasetPresenter.displayName: Expression profiling of C. parvum life cycle stages post-infection
datasetPresenter.description:
C. parvum oocysts (IOWA strain) were stored at 4°C. HCT8 cell infection was carried out according to previously reported conditions. Oocysts were counted using a hemocytometer and 2-2.5 x 107 oocysts were added to each culture dish at time (t) = 0 hr and incubated at 37°C and 5% CO2 After visual confirmation of excystation and attachment in culture (t= 2 hr), all samples were rinsed with warmed 1x Hanks buffered saline solution (HBSS). Infected cell cultures were lysed in TRIzol (Invitrogen) at 2, 6, 12, 24, 36, 48, and 72 hours post infection and stored at -80°C until RNA isolation. RNA was isolated from the samples and DNA contamination was degraded utilizing the Turbo DNA-free kit. cDNA synthesis was accomplished using Superscript III cDNA synthesis kit. Real Time PCR utilizing C. parvum 18S ribosomal RNA primers was completed to verify lack of DNA contamination as well as confirmation of successful cDNA synthesis for all 7 time points over 4 independent infection time courses (biological replicates).

For RT-PCR, Twenty microliter reactions were constructed using a 4 ul of template from a 1:100 dilution of synthesized cDNA (2 ug RNA starting concentration), 0.1 uM primer pairs and 2x AccuQuant SYBR Green SuperMix, with Low Rox (Quanta BioSciences, Inc.). RT-PCR was run on Stratagene Mx3000P or Mx3005P thermacyclers , with cycle conditions of: 1 cycle of initial denaturation (95°C for 1 minute), 45 PCR cycles (95°C for 1 minute, 58°C for 30 seconds and ramping to 60°C for 30s). Amplification was followed by melt curve generation via 1 minute at 95°C ramping down to 57°C in 2 degree intervals followed by ramping back up to 95°C for 30 seconds.

Primers for individual genes were tested on C. parvum genomic DNA for amplicon formation and efficiency. RT-PCR of the infection time course cDNA was performed in a 96 well format, with each of the 3281 gene primers (12 per plate) normalized to the corresponding time point's 18s rRNA amplification on each plate. Because of the high-throughput nature, each gene of interests' initial RNA concentration was estimated by fitting a 4 point logistic curve to the raw fluorescence amplification plot for each gene and 18s rRNA reactions. Post-normalization the median of the replicates (2-7 with an average of 4) was calculated for each time point. Standardization was performed relative to the maximum expression of a gene across time points

1Department of Parasitology, Institute of Medical Science. 2Department of Medical Genomics, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo. 3National Research Center for Protozoan Diseases, Obihoro University of Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine. 4Department of Protozoal Diseases, Graduate School of Medicine, Osaka City University.
